The seals and all controls associated with this pump are checked to make sure they are operable.  Upon verification of the three units, ventilation, leak detectors, and scrubber, the system is then activated to verify operation.

Alternative systems are in tact if failure of engineering or administrative controls were to occur.  In the event of a failure of the ventilation system, should there be a leak in the feed room or tank room, the caustic scrubber would still be activated automatically.  Upon investigation of these units, if it is found that the ventilators failed to shut down, the ability to manually override them and to manually shut them down by turning off the power in the motor control center room is available.

In the event that there is a malfunctioning leak detector, a number of things could occur.  If a leak detector has a weak cell or a bad battery, these two scenarios will activate the alarm system.  Upon investigating the alarm, the operator can determine whether it is a true leak or a malfunction of the system using a portable gas monitor.  If it is determined that the leak detector has malfunctioned, the system does have the ability to lock that particular unit out of the sequence.  This does not disarm the other five units that are in place.  The likelihood of having all six malfunction is remote.

If for some reason, the caustic scrubber pump would not run automatically, there is a manual override available to kick the pump on.  If the caustic pump will not run automatically or manually and it has been verified by using portable leak detectors that there is a leak of such magnitude that plant personnel cannot handle it, an emergency call will be initiated to the Division of Fire and to DEEM to request assistance with the leak.

Operations and procedures are very similar for sulfur dioxide

.  The sulfur dioxide tank room and feed room also have ventilation systems.  Sulfur dioxide leak detection is utilized, and there are two leak detector systems located in the sulfur dioxide storage room and one in the feed room.

In the event of a sulfur dioxide leak in the feed or tank room, the following systems will be activated.  If a leak detector detects sulfur dioxide gas, the ventilation systems and the alarm systems will be activated.  The alarm system consists of both an audible and visual alarm inside and outside the building, and on the main computer.  The ventilation systems will shut down when the leak detectors are activated.  Following the ventilation shutdown, the scrubber system will immediately be activated, thus removing the contaminated air from the feed or storage room via intake piping.  Sulfur dioxide gas will settle to the lower portions of the room, where the air intake piping is located, allowing it to be picked up and pulled into the caustic tank room where it is passed through the caustic solution.  This caustic solution neutralizes the sulfur dioxide gas that is in the air and returns the scrubbed air back into the sulfur dioxide room.


Executive Summary	cont:


Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant has a comprehensive and thorough emergency response plan.  In the event of a chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak or spill, all personnel are trained to immediately proceed with the following:

1. Notify Plant Operations Supervisor Senior and then the Solids Process Supervisor.

2. Plant Operations, Solids Process Supervisor, or their designee along Plant Operator on duty will investigate the leak.  A minor leak is a release of less than 10 lbs while a major leak is a release of more than 10 lbs.

3. Minor leak - Plant Operator on duty and Supervisor or designee to repair.

4. Major leak - initiate chlorine evacuation plan.

5. Notify LFUCG Fire Department

ch WWTP is familiar with the facility.

Emergency notification to the public in the event of a Hazardous Materials release incident from the Town Branch Plant has been correlated with the Fayette County Emergency Planning Committee.  Response to a large chemical release at the Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant will include, but not be limited to the following agencies:  Lexington Fire Department, Fayette County LEPC, and DEEM.  Other responding agencies are:  State Fire Marshall's Office, Kentucky Emergency Response Commission (KERC), Kentucky DES Area Coordinator, Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Agency, Chemtrac, and public works personnel.

Proper equipment and process controls of the plant facilitate a safe environment at Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant.  To ensure smooth and continuous accident free operation, the LFUCG and its employees are involved with every day processes, training and maintenance.  The LFUCG recognizes the importance of their operations to the environment and to the surrounding community.  To ensure quality management and control, proactive risk management is in effect every hour of the day.

Proper and thorough training of the employees is emphasized greatly.  It is important to have well-trained and skilled people handling the day-to-day operations and maintenance checks at the facility on a daily basis.  Initially, each employee involved in an operating process shall be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures.  Refresher training is given every year to each employee involved in operating processes to ensure that employees understand and adhere to the current operating procedures.  Monthly safety meetings are held on specific topics to all employees at the facility and five-minute tailgate meetings are held on a weekly basis on safety related issues.  The LFUCG installs the importance of safety and proper procedures to its entire employee.



Executive Summary	cont:

Safety inspections of the plant are also conducted on a routine basis and are determined and monitored electronically through the LFUCG database.  Once a month, a full safety inspection of the entire plant is conducted.  All records are sent to administration and inspections are kept on a monthly file in the administration building.

To date, Town Branch has not had to deal with any offsite consequences related to the facility.  Through preventive maintenance and proactive management, the LFUCG will continue to offer this quality operation. The worst-case scenario for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide was modeled to determine offsite consequence analysis.  The EPA defines a worst-case release as the following:

* The release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure, and

* The release that results in the greatest distance to the endpoint for the regulated toxic substance.

Only passive mitigation measures were considered for the off-site consequence analysis for both scenarios (No active mitigation measures were considered).  The only passive mitigation at Town Branch applicable for these scenarios was enclosure of the toxic gases in the building.

The maximum quantity of chlorine at any given time is no more then 20 tons and no more then 8 tons for sulfur dioxide. The largest quantity of both chemicals were determined by taking into account administrative controls rather than absolute capacity of the pipes.  Town Branch uses administrative controls that limit the quantity of chlorine and sulfur dioxide that can be stored in a pipe at any one time.

The toxic worst-case release for chlorine via a pipe leak at Town Branch, using only passive mitigation measures is 8,000 lbs with a release rate of 440 lbs/min.  The duration of the release is 10 minutes with wind speed calculated at 1.5 m/sec.  Considering these factors, the maximum effected radius or distance to the endpoint is calculated at 2 miles (based on EPA's OCA Guidance Reference Tables for Chlorine Gas).  Within this 2-mile radius, approximately 66,000 people could potentially be affected.  Residences, schools, hospitals, and recreation areas are all within this specified area and could potentially be affected.

The toxic worst-case release for anhydrous sulfur dioxide via a pipe leak, using passive mitigation measures is 4,000 lbs with a release rate of 220 lbs/min.  The duration of the release is 10 minutes with

wind speed calculated at 1.5 m/sec.  Considering these factors, the maximum effected radius or distance to the endpoint is factored at 1.3 miles (based on EPA's OCA Guidance Reference Tables for Chlorine Gas).  Within this 1.3 miles radius, approximately 40,501 people could potentially be affected.  Residences, schools, hospitals, and recreation areas are all within this specified area and could potentially be affected.

Executive Summary	cont:


Alternative releases were also modeled for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The alternative releases depict a more accurate picture of offsite consequence analysis and are more realistic than the worse case scenarios.  Passive and active mitigation measures were used to determine the alternative release scenarios.

The passive mitigation considered for both alternative scenarios was enclosure and active mitigation considered was the scrubbing facility.  Modeling for the alternative releases was based on EPA's OCA Guidance Reference Tables and Equations for gas pipe leaks.

The maximum quantity release for chlorine at Town Branch through a pipe leak, using passive and active mitigation measures is 6 lbs with a release rate of 0.1 lbs/min.  The duration of the release is 60 minutes with wind speed calculated at 3.0 m/sec.  Considering these factors, the realistic distance to an endpoint or offsite analysis is actually 0.10 mile with only 27 people affected.  The number is significantly reduced from the worse case scenario due to the active mitigation measures in place at the facility.  The scrubbing facility at Town Branch operates at 99% efficiency and is devised to remediate any chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak in the building.  The scrubbing process is further described below.

The maximum quantity release for sulfur dioxide at Town Branch using passive and active mitigation measures to 6 lbs with a release rate of 0.1 lbs/min.  The duration of the release is 60 minutes with wind speed calculated at 3.0 m/sec.

Executive Summary		


	Risk Management Plan
	Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant

This Risk Management Plan for Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant has been prepared in accordance with EPA Risk Management and is designed specifically for the above-specified location.  Town Branch Waste Water Treatment Plant is located in Lexington, Kentucky, 301 Lisle Industrial Avenue and is operated by the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government - Division of Sanitary Sewers. The primary function of this facility is the treatment of wastewater, in doing so chlorine is used for disinfection purposes and sulfur dioxide is for the neutralization of chlorine in plant effluent.  The probability of a release at this facility is classified as low to medium.  The chlorine storage building with a full scrubbing facility should prevent any major release from leaving the area.  Should a leak of a chlorine cylinder or sulfur dioxide cylinder occur, the onsite personnel (LFUCG employees) and surrounding population would be immediately vulnerable to exposure.  In the event of a release, there may be possible human health impacts to on-site employees.  A residential area to the North as well as property and the environment would be affected.  Contamination near the facility is possible.  A worse case release could affect an area over 2.0 mile radius and impact a sizeable residential and institutional population.  The Lexington Fayette Urban County Government (LFUCG) Division of Sanitary Sewers has invested ample and considerable time in devising and implementing accidental release prevention programs and emergency response policies.

Town Branch Wastewater Treatment Plant applies a holistic and proactive approach towards risk management.  The LFUCG has devised a reliable maintenance program, identifying management policies, preventive maintenance practices, plans, and procedures to identify and minimize risk at the plant.  Preventive maintenance consists of daily and weekly

checks of plant equipment.  All equipment is loaded on a database maintained by the LFUCG.  A data sheet is printed out daily indicating the maintenance and check schedule of all equipment and procedures.

The LFUCG manages risk proactively by reduction and avoidance.  To date no accidents or leaks have occurred at the Town Branch facility.  Management and employees of the LFUCG reduce risk by conducting manual inspections and routine maintenance checks.  The LFUCG identifies, evaluates, and analyzes potential risk situations in order to minimize a potential hazardous event at the plant.

In the unlikely event that a chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak would occur, LFUCG employees, and the LFUCG Fire Department are well prepared and trained to remediate and or mitigate the situation.  LFUCG employees are trained in handling chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  They are also trained on initial startup procedures, normal operating procedures, temporary operating procedures, emergency operating procedures, emergency shutdown procedures, normal shutdown procedures, and startup following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown procedure.

In addition, the chlorine and sulfur dioxide rooms of the plant have been designed such that even in worst-case scenarios, minimal levels of toxic gas will be released into the atmosphere.  If a chlorine leak does occur it will be detected by leak detectors in the chlorine room or in the pump room.  In the event of a chlorine leak in the feed room, or the tank storage room, the following systems would be activated.  If a leak detector detects chlorine gas, the ventilation systems and the alarm systems will be activated.    The alarm system consists of both an audible and a visual alarm in the building.  There will also be a visual alarm and audible alarm outside the building.  An alarm is also on the main computer systems, so if an operator is in the computer room he will see and hear the alarm.  When the leak detectors are activated, they will cause the ventilation systems to shut down.  Following the shut down of the ventilation system, the scrubber system is immediately automatically activated.  This system will remove the contaminated air from the feed or storage room via intake piping.  Chlorine gas will settle to the lower portions of the room, where the air intake piping is located, allowing it to be picked up and pulled into the caustic tank room where it is passed through the caustic solution.  This solution neutralizes the chlorine gas that is in the air and returns the scrubbed air back into the chlorine tank storage room and feed room.
